newsitem.title: USA: Military removes mystery canister from New Orleans.
newsitem.headline: Military removes mystery canister from New Orleans.

text.p: A mysterious canister found last week at New Orleans International Airport will be taken by army specialists to the Aberdeen Proving Ground for further inspection, authorities said on Thursday.

The 12-inch-long pressurized stainless steel canister was found on May 22 by airport security when an unidentified man tried to pass it through an X-ray machine en route to the concourse, airport authorities said.

Officials said the passenger said he could not open the cylinder because it would release a noxious odour. The man fled when security officers tried to question him, airport spokeswoman Michelle Duffourc said.

The Army Chemical Biological Defence Command will use special X-ray equipment to determine its contents and then take it to a laboratory at the Maryland facility for analysis, command spokeswoman Suzanne Fournier told Reuters on Thursday.
"We don't know how much time it will take to analyse. That depends on the initial findings," she said.

New Orleans authorities, fearing the canister was an explosive, first took it to a burn pit in a distant part of the airport before handing it over to the Environmental Protection Agency as a potentially hazardous material.

The EPA then called in military assistance, EPA spokesman John Casper told Reuters. The three-man team from the Technical Escord Detachment at Pine Bluff, Ark. will repack the canister into a hazardous material protective drum and then escort the drum to Maryland on a C-12 J2 military aircraft, Fournier said.
A description of the man carrying the canister was not released by authorities.
